items.content_html: This PR renames and moves all console function pages to mark them as static. Compliments BCD PR mdn/browser-compat-data#20178.
items.title: Mark all console functions as static

items.content_html:
Description

This PR mainly switch to workflow_call instead of workflow_run event to prevent calling "PR review companion" when not necessary.

To achieve this, and take this opportunity to improve the code, the following changes were made:

  1. Use pull_request_target event instead of pull_request, with the former event, the GITHUB_TOKEN has write permissions and the jobs could access GitHub secrets (we are using secrets to store the AK, SK).
  2. Set the permissions of the "tests" job to read-all to avoid accidental writes to the repo.
  3. Run the "PR review companion" as a spread job (named "review") in "PR test", so we could use if condition to skip unnecessary runs,
    Set the permissions of "review" job to write-all, so the deployer could create comment in PRs.
    Add secrets: inherit to inherit the secrets from the parent workflow so the reusable workflow could access all secrets. (tested in: yin1999#8, https://github.com/yin1999/content/actions/runs/6769815012/job/18397036827?pr=8#step:10:34)
  4. Use actions/download-artifact instead of js scripts, as the shared "PR review companion" workflow is a spread job in "PR test" now, we could use this action to download and unzip artifacts (simplifies the steps).

Security statement

Because the GITHUB_TOKEN generated in workflows that triggered by pull_request_target event has write permissions, we need to avoid malicious damage to the repo by the PR author.

  1. Set permissions to different jobs: as the first job would run js scripts which could be modified by PR authors, set the permission of this job to read-all (as we still need the GITHUB_TOKEN to access some resouces).
  2. The pull_request_target event would trigger the workflow runs with the main version of workflows (including the shared workflows - "PR review companion"). This has been tested by Onkar - yin1999#6, and has been documented by GitHub Docs:

    Although the workflow runs in the context of the base of the pull request, you should make sure that you do not check out, build, or run untrusted code from the pull request with this event.

  3. The workflow triggered by pull_request_target event could also access GitHub secrets. But GitHub Actions can only read a secret if you explicitly include the secret in a workflow.

Related issues and pull requests

implementation of: #28579 (comment)
Previous attempt: #28617
items.title: refactor(ci/pr-review): use `workflow_call` instead of `workflow_run` event (v2)

items.content_html:
Description

Nit: updated sounds like changed from one to another, while upgraded sounds like something going from good to better (like insecure -> secure in this case) so I changed it to upgraded.

Motivation

  • Matches the header name: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Upgrade-Insecure-Requests
  • Describes the behavior more explicitly
items.title: Changed CSP page's wording to more explicitly describe the behavior

items.content_html:
This is the content fixes related to this update mdn/django-locallibrary-tutorial#124

The update fixes #27895 by preventing books and authors from being deleted if there are any dependencies - i.e. books that use the author, or bookinstances that use the book.
This is a change for authors which previously just set the author in the book to null if the corresponding record was deleted.
This was needed because the current code falls over if you delete a book that has a dependent bookinstance, but the instructions say "just copy the Author approach".

This is partial. It's up to the authentication section - so more to do. Particularly in the forms section.
items.title: Django fixes to allow safe deletion of Books

items.content_html:
Description

The original example shows serializing and de-serializing BigInt in-place, and then comments that it is possible to generalize it. The new example shows a more generic approach, but mentions the potential downsides to it, and suggests the more specific approach as an alternative.

Motivation

I had gone through the practice of creating more specific replacers/revivers for JSON and figured a more generic approach might be helpful to others.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update index.md with more generic replacer/reviver for BigInt

items.content_html:
Description

I rearranged and expanded the first paragraph at section "Examples > encodeURI() vs. encodeURIComponent()" to make it not confusing and easier to understand.

Motivation

Said section of the page "encodeURI()" was confusing because with the way it was worded, it could lead to the mistake of using encodeURIComponent() in a URL that had a query string, and this would result in a query string that would not work.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Clarify encodeURI() vs. encodeURIComponent() usage
